document.title: A Geometric View on Constrained M-Estimators

creator.personname: Yen-Huan Li, Ya-Ping Hsieh, Nissim Zerbib and Volkan Cevher

abstract.name: Abstract
abstract.p: We study the estimation error of constrained M-estimators, and derive explicit upper bounds on the expected estimation error determined by the Gaussian width of the constraint set. Both of the cases where the true parameter is on the boundary of the constraint set (matched constraint), and where the true parameter is strictly in the constraint set (mismatched constraint) are considered. For both cases, we derive novel universal estimation error bounds for regression in a generalized linear model with the canonical link function. Our error bound for the mismatched constraint case is minimax optimal in terms of its dependence on the sample size, for Gaussian linear regression by the Lasso.

para.p: LaboratoryforInformationandInferenceSystemsÉcolePolytechniqueFédéraledeLausanne

Consider a general statistical estimation problem. Let (y1,…,yn) be a sample following a probability distribution Pθ♮ in a given class :=P{Pθ:∈θRp}. We are interested in estimating the parameter θ♮, given (y1,…,yn) and P, under the high-dimensional setting where <np.
If θ♮ is known to satisfy ≤⁢g(θ♮)c for some continuous convex function g and positive constant c, we can consider a constrained M-estimator of the form

Math.text: formulae@(hat@(theta) element-of argument@((minimum _ theta)@(f _ n * theta colon theta element-of G)), G assign conditional-set@(theta element-of R ^ p, g * theta less= c))

para.p: We assume that fn is a continuously differentiable convex function, and the constraint set G is non-empty. For example, the Lasso [Tibshirani1996] corresponds to

for some ∈a1,…,anRp and positive constant c . A matrix ∈ΘR×dd can be vectorized as a corresponding vector ∈θRp, =d2p. In the low-rank matrix recovery problem [Candes2011b, Gunasekar2014], a popular estimator corresponds to

for some ∈A1,…,AnR×dd and positive constant c, where ∥⋅∥* denotes the nuclear norm. In general, fn can be the normalized negative log-likelihood function, or any properly defined function, and g depends on the a priori information on the structure of the parameter θ♮ [Bach2013a, Chandrasekaran2012, ElHalabi2015].
One can also consider a penalized M-estimator, given by

Math.text: (hat@(theta)) _ [penalized] element-of argument@((minimum _ (theta element-of R ^ p))@(f _ n * theta + rho _ n * g * theta))

para.p: for some positive constant ρn. The penalized M-estimator can be computed by fast proximal methods, provided that the proximal mapping of g is easy to compute [Beck2009, Nesterov2013]. This condition, however, is not always satisfied. For example, if g is the nuclear norm, computing the corresponding proximal mapping requires a full singular value decomposition (SVD) in the first few iterations, and hence is not scalable with the parameter dimension. In contrast, if we consider a constrained M-estimator and compute it by the Frank-Wolfe algorithm, each iteration of the algorithm requires a linear minimization oracle (LMO), which can be approximated efficiently by Lanczos’ algorithm [Jaggi2013]. The paper [Zhang2013] also shows that when g is a structured sparsity regularizer, the LMO can be much easier to compute than the proximal mapping.

If we consider a constrained M-estimator, setting the value of the constant c in (1) becomes a practical issue. For the case <c⁢g(θ♮), the estimation error is obviously bounded below by the distance between θ♮ and the constraint set G, and hence estimation consistency is impossible. Ideally we would like to set =c⁢g(θ♮), while in practice ⁢g(θ♮) is seldom known. The last case is when we have some estimate on ⁢g(θ♮), and choose c such that >c⁢g(θ♮). Some natural questions arise: Is estimation consistency possible? How fast will the estimation error decay with the sample size n? Does setting >c⁢g(θ♮) result in larger estimation error than setting =c⁢g(θ♮)? We review related works in Section 2, which shows that answers existed only for specific cases even when =c⁢g(θ♮).
In this paper, we provide a unified analysis for constrained M-estimators. Specifically,
We propose an elementary framework for analyzing any M-estimator applied to any statistical model in Section 3.

We obtain universal error bounds in terms of the Gaussian width, valid for all canonical GLMs. We consider the matched constraint case (=c⁢g(θ♮)) in Section 4, and the mismatched constraint case (>c⁢g(θ♮)) in Section 5.

To illustrate the universal error bounds, we specialize the universal error bound to Gaussian linear regression with arbitrary convex constraint, and regression in canonical GLMs with the ℓ1-constraint in Section 6, and obtain explicit results.
Our error bound for the Lasso applied to the Gaussian linear model is optimal in the minimax sense (cf. Section 7).

Existing results for penalized M-estimators [Banerjee2015, Bickel2009, Buhlmann2011, Honorio2014, Kakade2010, Negahban2012, Geer2013], which are for deterministic ρn’s, cannot directly recover our results, and vice versa. Indeed, by Lagrange duality, there exists some >ρn0 such that the constrained M-estimator in (1) is equivalent to the penalized M-estimator in (4). This correspondence, however, holds only for given realization of the sample (y1,…,yn), and hence ρn is a random variable depending on the sample. Conversely, for any penalized M-estimator ^θpenalized for some >ρn0, there exists a constant =c⁢g(^θpenalized) such that the corresponding constrained M-estimator (4) is equivalent to ^θpenalized. Note that =c⁢g(^θpenalized) is again a random variable and dependent on the sample. We are not aware of any existing work on characterizing the correspondence between the two formulations.

In [Oymak2013a, Oymak2013], the authors derived sharp estimation error bounds for regression in the linear model by constrained least squares (LS) estimators. The analysis in [Vershynin2014] provides a minimax estimation error bound for the same setting . There are some related works on learning a function in a function class [Koltchinskii2013a, Mendelson2014]. When the function class is linearly parametrized by vectors in Rp, and the function corresponding to θ♮ is in the function class, the L2-estimation error in the function class may be translated into the ℓ2-estimation error with respect to θ♮. A common limitation of [Koltchinskii2013a, Mendelson2014, Oymak2013, Oymak2013a, Vershynin2014] is that the results are not extendable to general non-linear statistical models.

Another research direction considers constrained estimation in possibly non-linear statistical models [Plan2013a, Plan2015, Plan2014a]. A constrained M-estimator for logistic regression was proposed and analyzed in [Plan2013a]. In [Plan2014a], the authors proposed and analyzed a universal projection-based estimator for regression in generalized linear models (GLMs). In [Plan2015], the authors analyzed the performance of the constrained LS estimator in GLMs. A common limitation of [Plan2013a, Plan2015, Plan2014a] is that the results are valid only for the specific proposed estimators, and they do not even apply to the constrained maximum-likelihood (ML) estimator, which is the most popular approach in practice. Moreover, the proposed estimators in [Plan2013a, Plan2015, Plan2014a] can only recover the true parameter up to a scale ambiguity.

We say that the constraint is matched if θ♮ lies on the boundary of G in (1) (or =c⁢g(θ♮)), and mismatched if θ♮ lies strictly in G (or <c⁢g(θ♮)). The analyses in [Oymak2013a, Oymak2013] require the constraint to be matched, while in practice the exact value of ⁢g(θ♮) is seldom known. The constraint in [Koltchinskii2013a] is always matched due to the special structure of quantum density operators. The error bounds in [Plan2013a, Vershynin2014] can be overly pessimistic, because they hold for all ∈θ♮G. The results in [Mendelson2014, Plan2015, Plan2014a] do not require a matched constraint and depend on θ♮; our result is of this kind. Recall that, however, [Mendelson2014] is limited to specific statistical models, and [Plan2015, Plan2014a] are limited to specific M-estimators.
To illustrate the basic idea of our framework, let us start with a simple setting, where fn is strongly convex with parameter >μ0, i.e.,

Math.text: list@(nabla@(f _ n) * y - nabla@(f _ n) * x, y - x) >= mu * ((norm@(y - x)) _ 2) ^ 2

para.p: for any ∈x,y⁢domf. Note that then ^θ is uniquely defined.
Define :ιg→Rp∪R{+∞} as the indicator function of the constraint set G; that is, =⁢ιG(θ)0 if ∈θG, and =⁢ιG(θ)+∞ otherwise. By the strong convexity of fn, we have

Math.text: list@(nabla@(f _ n) * hat@(theta) - nabla@(f _ n) * theta ^ natural, hat@(theta) - theta ^ natural) >= mu * ((norm@(hat@(theta) - theta ^ natural)) _ 2) ^ 2

para.p: By the convexity of ιg, or the monotonicity of the subdifferential mapping, we have

Math.text: list@(hat@(z) - z ^ natural, hat@(theta) - theta ^ natural) >= 0

para.p: for any ∈^z⁢∂ιg(^θ), and any ∈z♮⁢∂ιg(θ♮). Summing up (5) and (6), we obtain

Math.text: list@((nabla@(f _ n) * hat@(theta) + hat@(z)) - nabla@(f _ n) * theta ^ natural - z ^ natural, hat@(theta) - theta ^ natural) >= mu * ((norm@(hat@(theta) - theta ^ natural)) _ 2) ^ 2

para.p: for any ∈^z⁢∂ιg(^θ). By the optimality condition of ^θ, there exists some ∈^z⁢∂ιG(^θ) such that

Math.text: 0 = nabla@(f _ n) * hat@(theta) + hat@(z)

para.p: and hence we have

Math.text: list@(- nabla@(f _ n) * theta ^ natural - z ^ natural, hat@(theta) - theta ^ natural) >= mu * ((norm@(hat@(theta) - theta ^ natural)) _ 2) ^ 2

para.p: for any ∈z♮⁢∂ιg(θ♮). Since ⁢∂ιg(θ♮) is always a closed convex cone, we can choose =z♮0 and obtain

Math.text: list@(- nabla@(f _ n) * theta ^ natural, hat@(theta) - theta ^ natural) >= mu * ((norm@(hat@(theta) - theta ^ natural)) _ 2) ^ 2

para.p: Applying the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality to the left-hand side, we obtain

Math.text: (norm@(nabla@(f _ n) * theta ^ natural)) _ 2 * (norm@(hat@(theta) - theta ^ natural)) _ 2 >= mu * ((norm@(hat@(theta) - theta ^ natural)) _ 2) ^ 2
(norm@(nabla@(f _ n) * theta ^ natural)) _ 2 * (norm@(hat@(theta) - theta ^ natural)) _ 2 >= mu * ((norm@(hat@(theta) - theta ^ natural)) _ 2) ^ 2

para.p: or

Math.text: (norm@(hat@(theta) - theta ^ natural)) _ 2 less= (1 / mu) * (norm@(nabla@(f _ n) * theta ^ natural)) _ 2

para.p: Taking expectations on both sides, we immediately obtain the following estimation error bound:

Math.text: E * (norm@(hat@(theta) - theta ^ natural)) _ 2 less= (1 / mu) * E * (norm@(nabla@(f _ n) * theta ^ natural)) _ 2

para.p: The gradient at the true parameter, ⁢∇fn(θ♮), usually concentrates around 0 with high probability.
The simple error bound (10) is not desirable for two reasons:
In the high-dimensional setting where <np, fn cannot be strongly convex even for the basic LS estimator.
It does not depend on the choice of g.
We address the first issue in Section 3.2, and the second issue in Section 3.3.

Note that in order to facilitate the arguments in the previous sub-section, we only require (5) to hold for ^θ and θ♮, instead of any two vectors in Rp. Therefore, we only need fn to satisfy some restricted notion of strong convexity. Similar (but not exactly the same) ideas had appeared in [Chandrasekaran2012, Negahban2012], and can be traced back to [Bickel2009, Geer2007].
The feasible set of g at θ♮, denoted by ⁢Fg(θ♮), is given by

Math.text: F _ g * theta ^ natural assign G - theta ^ natural = conditional-set@(theta - theta ^ natural, theta element-of G)

para.p: The feasible cone of g at θ♮, denoted by ¯⁢Fg(θ♮), is defined as the conic hull of ⁢Fg(θ♮).
By the definition of ^θ, the estimation error must satisfy ∈-^θθ♮⁢Fg(θ♮).
The function fn satisfies the restricted strong convexity (RSC) condition with parameter >μ0 if

Math.text: list@(nabla@(f _ n) * (theta ^ natural + e) - nabla@(f _ n) * theta ^ natural, e) >= mu * ((norm@(e)) _ 2) ^ 2

para.p: for any ∈e⁢Fg(θ♮).
If fn is twice continuously differentiable, we have a sufficient condition.

p.text: The function fn satisfies the RSC condition with parameter >μ0 if

Math.text: list@(e, (nabla ^ 2)@(f _ n) * (theta ^ natural + lambda * e) * e) >= mu * ((norm@(e)) _ 2) ^ 2

para.p: The uniqueness of ^θ and the derivation of the error bound in Section 3.1 are still valid even when <np, as long as fn satisfies the RSC condition with some parameter >μ0.
We address the dependence of the estimation error on the choice of g, and derive a refined error bound in this sub-section.
We note that

Math.text: list@(- nabla@(f _ n) * theta ^ natural, hat@(theta) - theta ^ natural) = (norm@(Pi _ (overline@(hat@(theta) - theta ^ natural)) * (- nabla@(f _ n) * theta ^ natural))) _ 2 * (norm@(hat@(theta) - theta ^ natural)) _ 2

para.p: where ⁢Π¯-^θθ♮(⋅) denotes the projection onto the conic hull of {-^θθ♮} (which is a half-line or {0}). This implies, by (8),

Math.text: (norm@(Pi _ (overline@(hat@(theta) - theta ^ natural)) * (- nabla@(f _ n) * theta ^ natural))) _ 2 >= mu * (norm@(hat@(theta) - theta ^ natural)) _ 2

para.p: The left-hand side, however, is not tractable due to its dependence on ^θ. As ∈-^θθ♮¯⁢Fg(θ♮) by definition, we consider a looser bound:

Math.text: (norm@(Pi _ (overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural)) * (- nabla@(f _ n) * theta ^ natural))) _ 2 >= mu * (norm@(hat@(theta) - theta ^ natural)) _ 2

para.p: where ⁢Π¯⁢Fg(θ♮)(⋅) denotes projection onto the feasible cone ¯⁢Fg(θ♮).
Taking expectations on both sides, we obtain the following lemma.

p.text: Assume that fn satisfies the RSC condition with parameter >μ0. Then ^θ is uniquely defined, and satisfies

Math.text: E * (norm@(hat@(theta) - theta ^ natural)) _ 2 less= (1 / mu) * E * (norm@(Pi _ (overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural)) * (- nabla@(f _ n) * theta ^ natural))) _ 2

para.p: Since -⁢∇fn(θ♮) is a descent direction of fn, if its direction is coherent with the feasible cone ¯⁢Fg(θ♮), we may find some point ^θ′ far away from θ♮ in the feasible set ⁢Fg(θ♮) such that ⁢fn(^θ′) is much smaller than ⁢fn(θ♮), and hence the estimation error can be large. This provides an intuitive interpretation of the lemma.
Since projection onto a closed convex set is a non-expansive mapping, we have

Math.text: (norm@(Pi _ (overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural)) * (- nabla@(f _ n) * theta ^ natural))) _ 2 less= (norm@(nabla@(f _ n) * theta ^ natural)) _ 2

para.p: so the error bound is always no larger than the one in Section 3.1.
Lemma 3.2 is the theoretical foundation of the rest of this paper.

section.title: 4Estimation Error Bound in Terms of the Gaussian Width

para.p: We apply Lemma 3.2 to constrained ML estimators in a GLM with the canonical link function. Examples of a canonical GLM include the Gaussian linear, logistic, gamma, and Poisson regression models.

Let ∈θ♮Rp be the parameter to be estimated, or the unknown vector of regression coefficients. In a canonical GLM, the negative log-likelihood of a sample y, given θ♮, is of the form (up to scaling and shifting by some constants)

Math.text: L * list@(y, theta ^ natural) = y * list@(a _ i, theta ^ natural) - b * list@(a _ i, theta ^ natural)

para.p: where ∈a1,…,anRp are given, and we assume that b is some given concave function. Let ∈(y1,…,yn)Rn be the sample. The constrained ML estimator is given by (1) with

Math.text: f _ n * theta assign (1 / n) * ((sum _ (i = 1)) ^ n)@(L * open-interval@(y _ i, theta))

para.p: and g being some continuous convex function. For simplicity, we consider the case where =c⁢g(θ♮) in this section; we address the case where >c⁢g(θ♮) in Section 5.
We specialize Lemma 3.2 to the canonical GLM and obtain the following theorem.
Let ⊆CRp. The Gaussian width of C is given by

Math.text: omega _ t * C assign E * (supremum _ (v element-of C intersection t * S ^ (p - 1)))@(set@(list@(h, v)))

para.p: where :=h(h1,…,hp) is a vector of i.i.d. standard Gaussian random variables, and S-p1 denotes the unit ℓ2-sphere in Rp.

p.text: Consider the canonical GLM and the corresponding ML estimator described above for =c⁢g(θ♮). Assume that the entries of a1,…,an are either all i.i.d. standard Gaussian or all i.i.d. Rademacher random variables (random variables taking values in {+1,-1} with equal probability), and fn satisfies the RSC condition for >μ0 with probability at least /12. Then

Math.text: E * (norm@(hat@(theta) - theta ^ natural)) _ 2 less= 2 * square-root@(2 * pi) * sigma _ maximum * ((omega _ 1 * overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural)) / (mu * square-root@(n)))

para.p: Note that the expectation is with respect to A and ε, conditioned on the event that the RSC condition holds.

The feasible cone ¯⁢Fg(θ♮) coincides with the tangent cone of g at θ♮ defined in [Chandrasekaran2012]. Therefore, to evaluate the estimation error bound, we only need to evaluate the Gaussian width of the corresponding tangent cone. We note that there are already many results for a variety of commonly used regularization functions, such as the ℓ1-norm, nuclear norm, total variation semi-norm, and general atomic norms [Cai2013, Chandrasekaran2012, Foygel2014, Plan2013a, Rao2012, Vershynin2014]. Therefore, for most of the applications, we only need to plug in an existing bound on the Gaussian width.

Finally, we would like to emphasize that the Gaussian width in Theorem 4.1 comes from bounding the random process induced by the random gradient ⁢∇fn(θ♮) (cf. the proof of Theorem 4.1), instead of being a consequence of applying Gordon’s Lemma. That is, our result is essentially different from those in [Chandrasekaran2012, Oymak2013a, Oymak2013].
In this section, we discuss the effect of a mismatched constraint for ML regression in a canonical GLM. Recall that the constraint set G is called mismatched if >c⁢g(θ♮) in (1).

The notion of the RSC in Definition 3.2 is no longer meaningful when the constraint set is mismatched. Take ML regression in the Gaussian linear model for example, for which the corresponding fn is given in (2). Let ∈AR×np be defined as in Theorem 4.1. The RSC condition requires

Math.text: list@(nabla@(f _ n) * (theta ^ natural + e) - nabla@(f _ n) * theta ^ natural, e) = (1 / n) * ((norm@(A * e)) _ 2) ^ 2 >= mu * ((norm@(e)) _ 2) ^ 2

para.p: for some >μ0 and all ∈e¯⁢Fg(θ♮), where we say ∈e¯⁢Fg(θ♮) instead of ∈e⁢Fg(θ♮) because A is a linear operator. Since when the constraint is mismatched, ¯⁢Fg(θ♮) is the whole space Rp, the RSC condition requires A to be a non-singular matrix. This cannot be true in the high-dimensional setting, where ∈AR×np and <np.
Our Approach: Let >t0 and denote by B the unit ℓ2-ball in Rp. We partition the feasible set ⁢Fg(θ♮) as

Math.text: F _ g * theta ^ natural = (F _ g * theta ^ natural intersection t * B) union (F _ g * theta ^ natural set-minus t * B)

para.p: When t is large enough, the conic hull of (∖⁢Fg(θ♮)⁢tB) will not be the whole space Rp, so it is possible to have restricted strong convexity on (∖⁢Fg(θ♮)⁢tB) when <np. If the error vector -^θθ♮ lies in (∖⁢Fg(θ♮)⁢tB), we can obtain an error bound, say, ~t, as in Section 4; otherwise, if the error vector lies in Bt, a naïve error bound is the radius of the ball, i.e., t. Finally, we can bound the estimation error from above by the maximum of ~t and t. Note that ~t is implicitly dependent on t.

The arguments in the previous paragraph can be made precise as in Lemma 5.1, which is an analogue of Lemma 3.2 in the mismatched case. Lemma 5.1 holds for arbitrary constrained M-estimators of the form (1) and statistical models.

p.text: Suppose that for some >t0, we have

Math.text: list@(nabla@(f _ n) * (theta ^ natural + e) - nabla@(f _ n) * theta ^ natural, e) >= mu * ((norm@(e)) _ 2) ^ 2
E * (norm@(hat@(theta) - theta ^ natural)) _ 2 less= t + E * (norm@(Pi _ (overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural set-minus t * B)) * (- nabla@(f _ n) * theta ^ natural))) _ 2

para.p: We can also prove an analogue of Theorem 4.1 for constrained ML regression in a canonical GLM.

p.text: Consider the canonical GLM and the corresponding ML estimator described in Section 4, for >c⁢g(θ♮). Let A be defined as in Theorem 4.1 and let >t0. Suppose that (14) holds true with for some >μ0 with probability at least /12. Then we have

Math.text: E * (norm@(hat@(theta) - theta ^ natural)) _ 2 less= t + 2 * square-root@(2 * pi) * sigma _ maximum * ((omega _ 1 * overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural set-minus t * B)) / (mu * square-root@(n)))

p.text: where σmax is defined as in Theorem 4.1.

para.p: The proofs of Lemma 5.1 and Corollary 5.2 are similar to the proofs of Lemma 3.2 and Theorem 4.1, respectively.

Once the conditions (11) and (14) are verified, our results Theorem 4.1 and Corollary 5.2 immediately follow. We explicitly verify the conditions for two applications and obtain the corresponding estimation error bounds.
The first application is regression by the constrained LS estimator in a Gaussian linear model. Let ∈θ♮Rp and a1,…,an be vectors in Rp. The sample is given by

Math.text: formulae@(y _ i = list@(a _ i, theta ^ natural) + sigma * w _ i, i = list@(1, ldots, n))

para.p: for some >σ0, where w1,…,wn are i.i.d. standard Gaussian random variables. We consider the constrained LS estimator, for which fn is given by (2), and :=G{θ:≤⁢g(θ)c} for some ≥c⁢g(θ♮), where g can be any convex continuous function.

p.text: Consider the Gaussian linear model and the constrained LS estimator described above. Assume that the entries of a1,…,an are either all i.i.d. standard Gaussian or all i.i.d. Rademacher random variables. Let ∈ϵ(0,1). For any ≥t0, there exist positive constants c1 and c2 such that if

Math.text: square-root@(n) >= (c _ 1 * alpha ^ 2 * omega _ 1 * overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural set-minus t * B)) / epsilon
E * (norm@(hat@(theta) - theta ^ natural)) _ 2 less= t + 2 * square-root@(2 * pi) * sigma * ((omega _ 1 * overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural set-minus t * B)) / ((1 - epsilon) * square-root@(n)))

p.text: with probability at least >-1exp(-⁢c2ϵ2n)/12 when n is large enough.

para.p: When the constraint is matched, we can simply set =t0. Recall that t cannot be zero for the mismatched constraint case when <np (cf. Section 5). This remark also applies to Corollary 6.2 below.
For the mismatched constraint case, Corollary (6.1) is minimax optimal for the Lasso in the Gaussian linear model. We address this in Section 7.
Corollary 6.1 is consistent with [Oymak2013]. The result in [Oymak2013] is sharper, while Corollary 6.1 is more general as it also covers the mismatched constraint case.
The second application is ℓ1-constrained ML regression in a canonical GLM.

p.text: Consider the canonical GLM and the constrained ML estimator described in Section 4, for :=⁢g(θ)∥θ∥1 and ≥c∥θ♮∥. Assume that fn in (13) is twice continuously differentiable, and the entries of a1,…,an are i.i.d. Rademacher random variables. Let ∈ϵ(0,1). For any ≥t0, there exist positive constants c1, and c2 such that if (15) is satisfied, then we have

Math.text: E * (norm@(hat@(theta) - theta ^ natural)) _ 2 less= t + 2 * square-root@(2 * pi) * sigma _ maximum * ((omega _ 1 * overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural set-minus t * B)) / ((1 - epsilon) * square-root@(n)))

p.text: with probability at least >-1exp(⁢c2ϵ2n)/12 when n is large enough, where :=σmaxmaxi⁢varyi is bounded above by a constant independent of n.

para.p: To the best of our knowledge, there are not existing results for ℓ1-constrained ML regression in GLMs. Here we compare Corollary 6.2 with [Negahban2010], which provides an error bound for ℓ1-penalized ML estimators in GLMs . Recall that, however, the correspondence between the constrained and penalized estimators is currently unclear. When the constraint is matched and θ♮ is s-sparse, Corollary 6.2 states that when =n⁢Ω(⁢slog(/ps)),

Math.text: E * (norm@(hat@(theta) - theta ^ natural)) _ 2 = O * square-root@((s / n) * logarithm@(p / s))

para.p: by Proposition 3.10 in [Chandrasekaran2012], which essentially coincides with Corollary 5 in [Negahban2010]We cite [Negahban2010] instead of the published version [Negahban2012], because the estimation error bound only appears in [Negahban2010].. We note that [Negahban2010] only provides an error bound for the ℓ1-penalization case.
It has been shown that in a Gaussian linear model with G being an ℓ1-ball, any estimator ^θarbitrary must satisfy, with probability larger than /12,

Math.text: maximum _ (theta ^ natural element-of G) * (norm@((hat@(theta)) _ [arbitrary] - theta ^ natural)) _ 2 = Omega * n ^ (- 1 / 4)

para.p: under some technical conditions [Raskutti2011]. Now we show our error bound for the Lasso in Corollary 6.1 actually achieves the error decaying rate ⁢O(n-/14) in the mismatched constraint case, and hence cannot be essentially improved.
By the definition of the Gaussian width, we have, for any >t0,

Math.text: omega _ 1 * overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural set-minus t * B) = (omega _ t * overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural set-minus t * B)) / t = (omega _ t * F _ g * theta ^ natural) / t

para.p: and hence the estimation error bound in Corollary 16 can be written as

Math.text: E * (norm@(hat@(theta) - theta ^ natural)) _ 2 less= t + (C / t) * ((omega _ t * F _ g * theta ^ natural) / square-root@(n))

para.p: for some >C0, when n is large enough such that (15) is satisfied.
Define the global Gaussian width:

Math.text: omega * F _ g * theta ^ natural assign E * (supremum _ (v element-of F _ g * theta ^ natural))@(set@(list@(h, x)))

para.p: where ∈hRp is a vector of i.i.d. standard Gaussian random variables. By definition, ⁢ωt(⁢Fg(θ♮)) is bounded above by ⁢ω(⁢Fg(θ♮)), independent of n. Replacing ⁢ωt(⁢Fg(θ♮)) by ⁢ω(⁢Fg(θ♮)) in (18), we have a looser error upper bound:

Math.text: E * (norm@(hat@(theta) - theta ^ natural)) _ 2 less= t + (C / t) * ((omega * F _ g * theta ^ natural) / square-root@(n))

para.p: Minimizing this bound over all >t0, we obtain the ⁢O(n-/14) error decaying rate. Similar discussion can be found in [Plan2014a].

Note that by the elementary argument in Section 3, we arrive at an estimation error bound (12) that holds surely. It is possible to derive a concentration-type error guarantee based on this sure error bound, which we are working on.

Our framework is not restricted to constraint sets of the form (1); it applies to any non-empty closed convex set G, as we only require ⁢ιG(⋅) to be proper closed convex in the proof. This observation is crucial to applying our framework to analyze constrained estimators for quantum tomography [Flammia2012, Gross2010] and photon-limited imaging systems [Raginsky2010], which we are studying.

In this paper, we consider a random matrix A, and discuss the expected estimation error with respect to both A and the sample (y1,…,yn). The extension to the the case where A is deterministic is technically non-trivial, and we have not obtained a satisfactory result. We address this in the remark following the proof of Theorem 4.1 in the appendix.
This work was supported in part by the European Commission under Grant MIRG-268398, ERC Future Proof, SNF 200021-132548, SNF 200021-146750 and SNF CRSII2-147633.
We have

Math.text: list@(nabla@(f _ n) * (theta ^ natural + e) - nabla@(f _ n) * theta ^ natural, e) = ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(list@(e, (nabla ^ 2)@(f _ n) * (theta ^ natural + lambda * e) * e) * differential-d@(lambda))
list@(nabla@(f _ n) * (theta ^ natural + e) - nabla@(f _ n) * theta ^ natural, e) = ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(list@(e, (nabla ^ 2)@(f _ n) * (theta ^ natural + lambda * e) * e) * differential-d@(lambda))

para.p: The right-hand side is always larger than ⁢μ∥e∥22 by assumption.
The main goal of the proof is to evaluate ⁢E∥⁢Π¯⁢Fg(θ♮)(-⁢∇fn(θ♮))∥2. Here the expectation is with respect to both A and the sample (yi)=i1,…,n.
We start with an equivalent formulation:

Math.text: E * (norm@(Pi _ (overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural)) * (- nabla@(f _ n) * theta ^ natural))) _ 2 = E * (supremum _ (v element-of overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural) intersection S ^ (p - 1)))@(set@(list@(- nabla@(f _ n) * theta ^ natural, v)))

para.p: where S-p1 denotes the unit ℓ2-sphere in Rp. It is well known that in a canonical GLM, we have

Math.text: nabla@(f _ n) * theta ^ natural = - (1 / n) * A ^ T * varepsilon

para.p: where :=ε(-yi⁢Eyi)=i1,…,n, and hence

Math.text: E * (norm@(Pi _ (overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural)) * (- nabla@(f _ n) * theta ^ natural))) _ 2 = (1 / n) * E * (supremum _ (v element-of overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural) intersection S ^ (p - 1)))@(set@(list@(A ^ T * varepsilon, v)))

para.p: To proceed, we need the following symmetrization inequality. The symmetrization inequality is different from the well-known symmetrization inequality by a Rademacher process, so we show it here for completeness.

p.text: Let ξ1,…,ξn be independent real-valued random variables, and let F be a class of real functions. We have

Math.text: E * (supremum _ (f element-of F))@(set@(((sum _ (i = 1)) ^ n)@(delimited-[]@(f * xi _ i - E * f * xi _ i)))) less= square-root@(2 * pi) * E * (supremum _ (f element-of F))@(set@(((sum _ (i = 1)) ^ n)@(h _ i * f * xi _ i)))

p.text: where h1,…,hn are i.i.d. standard Gaussian random variables.

para.p: In [Handel2014], the lemma is stated for the case when ξ1,…,ξn are i.i.d. The case when ξ1,…,ξn are not necessarily identical can be proved in a similar way, as noted in [Pollard1984].
By Lemma B.1, we have

Math.text: E * (supremum _ (v element-of overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural) intersection S ^ (p - 1)))@(set@(list@(A ^ T * varepsilon, v)) * ) = E * (supremum _ (v element-of overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural) intersection S ^ (p - 1)))@(set@(list@(varepsilon, A * v)))
E * (supremum _ (v element-of overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural) intersection S ^ (p - 1)))@(set@(list@(A ^ T * varepsilon, v)))
= E * (supremum _ (v element-of overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural) intersection S ^ (p - 1)))@(set@(list@(varepsilon, A * v)))
less= square-root@(2 * pi) * E * (supremum _ (v element-of overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural) intersection S ^ (p - 1)))@(set@(list@(h cdot varepsilon, A * v)))
less= square-root@(2 * pi) * E * (supremum _ (v element-of overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural) intersection S ^ (p - 1)))@(set@(list@(h cdot varepsilon, A * v)))

para.p: where :=⋅hε(⁢hiεi)=i1,…,n, and h1,…,hn are i.i.d. standard Gaussian random variables. Note that ⋅hε is a random Gaussian vector with zero mean and covariance matrix ∈ΣR×nn which is dependent on A in general; moreover, since the entries in ε are independent, Σ is a diagonal matrix with diagonal entries given by :=Σi,i⁢varyi. Define :=~h(~hi)=i1,…,n, where :=~hi⁢Σi,i-/12hiεi. Then ~h is a vector of i.i.d. standard Gaussian random variables; furthermore, it is still a vector of i.i.d. standard Gaussian random variables condition on A, and hence it is statistically independent of A.
Since ⋅hε and ⁢Σ~h have the same probability distribution, we can write

Math.text: E * (supremum _ (v element-of overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural) intersection S ^ (p - 1)))@(set@(list@(h cdot varepsilon, A * v))) = E * (supremum _ (v element-of overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural) intersection S ^ (p - 1)))@(set@(list@(square-root@(Sigma) * tilde@(h), A * v)))

para.p: Let :=T∩¯⁢Fg(θ♮)S-p1. Condition on any given A (and hence Σ), we consider two mean-zero Gaussian processes {Xt}∈tT and {Yt}∈tT defined as

Math.text: formulae@(X _ t assign list@(square-root@(Sigma) * tilde@(h), A * t), Y _ t assign sigma _ maximum * list@(tilde@(h), A * t))

para.p: where σ⁢max:=maxiΣi,i=maxi⁢varεi. We have, for any ∈t1,t2T,

Math.text: E * (absolute-value@(X _ t _ 1 - X _ t _ 2)) ^ 2 = ((norm@(Sigma * A * (t _ 1 - t _ 2))) _ 2) ^ 2 less= (sigma _ maximum) ^ 2 * ((norm@(A * (t _ 1 - t _ 2))) _ 2) ^ 2 = E * (absolute-value@(Y _ t _ 1 - Y _ t _ 2)) ^ 2

para.p: By Slepian’s lemma, this implies

Math.text: E * (supremum _ (t element-of T))@(X _ t) less= E * (supremum _ (t element-of T))@(Y _ t)

para.p: Since the inequality holds given any realization of A, we have

Math.text: E * (supremum _ (v element-of overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural) intersection S ^ (p - 1)))@(set@(list@(A ^ T * varepsilon, v))) less= square-root@(2 * pi) * sigma _ maximum * E * (supremum _ (v element-of overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural) intersection S ^ (p - 1)))@(set@(list@(tilde@(h), A * v)))
E * (supremum _ (v element-of overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural) intersection S ^ (p - 1)))@(set@(list@(A ^ T * varepsilon, v)))
absent less= square-root@(2 * pi) * sigma _ maximum * E * (supremum _ (v element-of overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural) intersection S ^ (p - 1)))@(set@(list@(tilde@(h), A * v)))
absent = square-root@(2 * pi) * sigma _ maximum * E * (supremum _ (v element-of overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural) intersection S ^ (p - 1)))@(set@(list@(A ^ T * tilde@(h), v)))
absent = square-root@(2 * pi) * sigma _ maximum * E * (supremum _ (v element-of overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural) intersection S ^ (p - 1)))@(set@(list@(A ^ T * tilde@(h), v)))

para.p: It remains to prove

Math.text: E * (supremum _ (v element-of overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural) intersection S ^ (p - 1)))@(set@(list@(A ^ T * tilde@(h), v))) less= square-root@(n) * omega _ 1 * overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural) assign square-root@(n) * E * (supremum _ (v element-of overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural) intersection S ^ (p - 1)))@(set@(list@(tilde@(h), v)))

para.p: We consider two cases:

If A has i.i.d. standard Gaussian entries, then condition on ~h, ⁢AT~h is a vector of mean-zero Gaussian random variables with covariance matrix ⁢∥~h∥2I, and hence has the same probablity distribution as ⁢∥~h∥¯h, where ¯h is a vector of i.i.d. standard Gaussian random variables independent of ~h. Therefore,

Math.text: E * (supremum _ (v element-of overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural) intersection S ^ (p - 1)))@(set@(list@(A ^ T * tilde@(h), v))) = E * (supremum _ (v element-of overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural) intersection S ^ (p - 1)))@(set@(list@(norm@(tilde@(h)) * bar@(h), v)))
E * (supremum _ (v element-of overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural) intersection S ^ (p - 1)))@(set@(list@(A ^ T * tilde@(h), v)))
absent = E * (supremum _ (v element-of overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural) intersection S ^ (p - 1)))@(set@(list@(norm@(tilde@(h)) * bar@(h), v)))
absent = E _ (tilde@(h)) * (norm@(tilde@(h))) _ 2 * E _ (bar@(h)) * (supremum _ (v element-of overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural) intersection S ^ (p - 1)))@(set@(list@(bar@(h), v)))
absent = E _ (tilde@(h)) * (norm@(tilde@(h))) _ 2 * E _ (bar@(h)) * (supremum _ (v element-of overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural) intersection S ^ (p - 1)))@(set@(list@(bar@(h), v)))
absent less= square-root@(n) * omega _ 1 * overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural)
absent less= square-root@(n) * omega _ 1 * overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural)

para.p: If A has i.i.d. Rademacher entries, then condition on A, ⁢AT~h is a vector of mean-zero Gaussian random variables with covariance matrix ⁢nI, and hence has the same probability distribution as ⁢n¯h, where ¯h is a vector of i.i.d. standard Gaussian random variables. Therefore,

Math.text: E * (supremum _ (v element-of overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural) intersection S ^ (p - 1)))@(set@(list@(A ^ T * tilde@(h), v))) = E * (supremum _ (v element-of overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural) intersection S ^ (p - 1)))@(set@(list@(square-root@(n) * bar@(h), v)))
E * (supremum _ (v element-of overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural) intersection S ^ (p - 1)))@(set@(list@(A ^ T * tilde@(h), v)))
absent = E * (supremum _ (v element-of overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural) intersection S ^ (p - 1)))@(set@(list@(square-root@(n) * bar@(h), v)))
absent = square-root@(n) * omega _ 1 * overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural)
absent = square-root@(n) * omega _ 1 * overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural)

para.p: In summary, we obtain

Math.text: E * (norm@(Pi _ (overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural)) * (- nabla@(f _ n) * theta ^ natural))) _ 2 less= square-root@(2 * pi) * sigma _ maximum * ((omega _ 1 * overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural)) / square-root@(n))

para.p: if the entries of A are i.i.d. standard Gaussian or Rademacher random variables, for a canonical GLM, where the expectation is with respect to both A and the sample (yi)=i1,…,n.
Let E denote that event that the RSC condition holds. Then we have

Math.text: E * (norm@(Pi _ (overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural)) * (- nabla@(f _ n) * theta ^ natural))) _ 2 = * P * E * E _ [A,(yi)|E] * (norm@(Pi _ (overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural)) * (- nabla@(f _ n) * theta ^ natural))) _ 2
E * (norm@(Pi _ (overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural)) * (- nabla@(f _ n) * theta ^ natural))) _ 2 = absent
* P * E * E _ [A,(yi)|E] * (norm@(Pi _ (overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural)) * (- nabla@(f _ n) * theta ^ natural))) _ 2
+ P * E ^ C * E _ [A,(yi)|EC] * (norm@(Pi _ (overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural)) * (- nabla@(f _ n) * theta ^ natural))) _ 2
+ P * E ^ C * E _ [A,(yi)|EC] * (norm@(Pi _ (overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural)) * (- nabla@(f _ n) * theta ^ natural))) _ 2

para.p: and hence

Math.text: E _ [A,(yi)|E] * (norm@(Pi _ (overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural)) * (- nabla@(f _ n) * theta ^ natural))) _ 2 less= (E * (norm@(Pi _ (overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural)) * (- nabla@(f _ n) * theta ^ natural))) _ 2) / (P * E)
E _ [A,(yi)|E] * (norm@(Pi _ (overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural)) * (- nabla@(f _ n) * theta ^ natural))) _ 2
absent less= (E * (norm@(Pi _ (overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural)) * (- nabla@(f _ n) * theta ^ natural))) _ 2) / (P * E)
absent less= 2 * E * (norm@(Pi _ (overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural)) * (- nabla@(f _ n) * theta ^ natural))) _ 2
absent less= 2 * E * (norm@(Pi _ (overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural)) * (- nabla@(f _ n) * theta ^ natural))) _ 2

para.p: where we applied the assumption that ≥⁢P(E)/12. By Lemma 3.2, this implies

Math.text: E _ [A,ε|E] * (norm@(hat@(theta) - theta ^ natural)) _ 2 less= (1 / mu) * E _ [A,(yi)|E] * (norm@(Pi _ (overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural)) * (- nabla@(f _ n) * theta ^ natural))) _ 2
E _ [A,ε|E] * (norm@(hat@(theta) - theta ^ natural)) _ 2
absent less= (1 / mu) * E _ [A,(yi)|E] * (norm@(Pi _ (overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural)) * (- nabla@(f _ n) * theta ^ natural))) _ 2
absent less= 2 * square-root@(2 * pi) * sigma _ maximum * ((omega _ 1 * overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural)) / (mu * square-root@(n)))
absent less= 2 * square-root@(2 * pi) * sigma _ maximum * ((omega _ 1 * overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural)) / (mu * square-root@(n)))

para.p: This completes the proof.

If we want to adapt this proof to the deterministic A case, a technical issue arises when bounding the right-hand side of (21). As the random process {~Xv:=⟨~h,v⟩}∈vV, where :=V∩¯⁢Fg(θ♮)S-p1, is a mean-zero Gaussian process, a standard approach is to bound sup∈vV~Xv by Slepian’s lemma. Note that, for any ∈v1,v2V,

Math.text: E * (absolute-value@((tilde@(X)) _ v _ 1 - (tilde@(X)) _ v _ 2)) ^ 2 = ((norm@(A * (v _ 1 - v _ 2))) _ 2) ^ 2

para.p: and hence an upper-bound on ⁢E|-~Xv1~Xv2|2 would depend on the largest eigenvalue of A. The largest eigenvalue of A, however, cannot be bounded above by a constant independent of n under the high-dimensional setting. Although we can weaken the requirement on A to a restricted smoothness condition as

Math.text: formulae@((norm@(A * v)) _ 2 less= square-root@(1 + epsilon) * (norm@(v)) _ 2, [for all ] * v element-of overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural) intersection S ^ (p - 1))

para.p: which, by Theorem E.1, holds with high probability. This condition does not imply
for some dimension-independent constant >C0, for all ∈v1,v2V.
Let :=e-^θθ♮. If ∈e∖⁢Fg(θ♮)⁢tB, following the proof of Theorem 4.1, we obtain

Math.text: (norm@(e)) _ 2 less= (1 / mu) * (norm@(Pi _ (overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural set-minus t * B)) * (- nabla@(f _ n) * theta ^ natural))) _ 2

para.p: where ¯∖⁢Fg(θ♮)⁢tB denotes the conic hull of ∖⁢Fg(θ♮)⁢tB. If ∈e⁢tB, we have the naïve bound: ≤∥e∥2t. Therefore,

Math.text: (norm@(e)) _ 2 less= maximum@(t, (1 / mu) * (norm@(Pi _ (overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural set-minus t * B)) * (- nabla@(f _ n) * theta ^ natural))) _ 2)
(norm@(e)) _ 2
absent less= maximum@(t, (1 / mu) * (norm@(Pi _ (overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural set-minus t * B)) * (- nabla@(f _ n) * theta ^ natural))) _ 2)
absent less= t + (1 / mu) * (norm@(Pi _ (overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural set-minus t * B)) * (- nabla@(f _ n) * theta ^ natural))) _ 2
absent less= t + (1 / mu) * (norm@(Pi _ (overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural set-minus t * B)) * (- nabla@(f _ n) * theta ^ natural))) _ 2

para.p: The lemma follows by taking expectations on both sides.
Let :=e-^θθ♮. If ∈e∖⁢Fg(θ♮)⁢tB, following the proof of Theorem 4.1, we can obtain

Math.text: E * (norm@(e)) _ 2 less= 2 * square-root@(2 * pi) * sigma _ maximum * ((omega _ 1 * overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural set-minus t * B)) / (mu * square-root@(n)))

para.p: otherwise, we can bound the expected estimation error from above by t. Therefore,

Math.text: E * (norm@(e)) _ 2 less= maximum@(t, 2 * square-root@(2 * pi) * sigma _ maximum * ((omega _ 1 * overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural set-minus t * B)) / (mu * square-root@(n))))
E * (norm@(e)) _ 2
absent less= maximum@(t, 2 * square-root@(2 * pi) * sigma _ maximum * ((omega _ 1 * overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural set-minus t * B)) / (mu * square-root@(n))))
absent less= t + 2 * square-root@(2 * pi) * sigma _ maximum * ((omega _ 1 * overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural set-minus t * B)) / (mu * square-root@(n)))
absent less= t + 2 * square-root@(2 * pi) * sigma _ maximum * ((omega _ 1 * overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural set-minus t * B)) / (mu * square-root@(n)))

appendix.title: Appendix EProof of Corollary 6.1 and Corollary 6.2

para.p: The proofs in this section rely on the following theorem [Mendelson2007].

p.text: Let ⊆TRp be star-shaped. Let ∈AR×np, <np, whose rows are i.i.d. isotropic subgaussian random vectors with subgaussian norm ≥α1, and let ∈ϵ(0,1). Then there exist constants c1 and c2 such that for all ∈xT satisfying

Math.text: (norm@(x)) _ 2 >= (gamma _ n) ^ * * open-interval@(epsilon / (c _ 1 * alpha ^ 2), T) assign infimum@(conditional-set@(t > 0, t >= (c _ 1 * alpha ^ 2 * omega _ t * T) / (epsilon * square-root@(n))))
(1 - epsilon) * ((norm@(x)) _ 2) ^ 2 less= ((norm@(A * x)) _ 2) ^ 2 / n less= (1 + epsilon) * ((norm@(x)) _ 2) ^ 2

para.p: We note that the sub-Gaussian norm of a vector of i.i.d. standard Gaussian entries or i.i.d. Rademacher entries is bounded above by a constant [Vershynin2012].
We prove by Corollary 5.2.
Let A be defined as in Theorem 4.1. We verify the condition (14) by Theorem E.1. Since =⁢ωt(¯∖⁢Fg(θ♮)⁢tB)⁢tω1(¯∖⁢Fg(θ♮)⁢tB), the condition (22) is equivalent to requiring

Math.text: square-root@(n) >= (c _ 1 * alpha ^ 2 * omega _ 1 * overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural set-minus t * B)) / epsilon

para.p: Once this inequality is satisfied, we can set =μ-1ϵ, and the condition (14) hold with probability at least -1exp(-/⁢c2ϵ2nα4). Note that σmax=⁢Ewi2=σ. This completes the proof.
We prove the corollary by Corollary 5.2.
It is known that

Math.text: (nabla ^ 2)@(f _ n) * theta = (1 / n) * A ^ T * D * theta * A

para.p: for the ML estimator in a canonical GLM, where A is defined as in Theorem 4.1, and ⁢D(θ) is a diagonal matrix; furthermore, there exists a continuous strictly positive function ϕ such that the (i,i)-th entry of ⁢D(θ) is given by ⁢ϕ(⟨ai,θ⟩). Since the entries of A are i.i.d. Rademacher random variables, for any ∈θG,

Math.text: absolute-value@(list@(a _ i, theta)) less= (norm@(a _ i)) _ infinity * (norm@(theta)) _ 1 less= c

para.p: By the extreme value theorem, the diagonal entries of ⁢D(θ) are bounded below by a constant >ν0 for all ∈θG, which is independent of n. Similarly, σmax is bounded above by a constant independent of n.
The rest of the proof is similar to the last paragraph in the previous sub-section. By Theorem E.1, if we choose n such that

Math.text: square-root@(n) >= (c * alpha ^ 2 * omega _ 1 * overline@(F _ g * theta ^ natural set-minus t * B)) / epsilon

para.p: then the condition (14) holds with probability at least -1exp(-/⁢c2ϵ2nα4) with =μ⁢ν(-1ϵ).
